Award.AwardTitle: NSF-RISE: Enhancement of Research and Educational Infrastructure in Nanobiomaterials Science and Engineering at Tuskegee University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Research Infrastructure for Science and Engineering (HBCU-RISE) activity within the Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (CREST) program supports the development of research capability at HBCUs that offer doctoral degrees in science and engineering disciplines. HBCU-RISE projects have a direct connection to the long-term plans of the host department(s) and the institutional mission, and plans for expanding institutional research capacity as well as increasing the production of doctoral students in science and engineering. With support from the National Science Foundation, Tuskegee University (TU) will implement comprehensive strategies designed to expand TU's research capabilities and using the research projects to enhance the educational experiences of the students. The combined research and education efforts are expected to expand the participation of groups underrepresented in Materials Science and Engineering and support the nation's efforts in building a robust STEM workforce. This project has the potential to be a model for increasing the number of minority students pursuing STEM degree programs and careers and addressing the deficit of female and minority faculty members in the discipline of Materials Science and Engineering.

This project will be carried out in TU's Department of Materials Science and Engineering (MSE) with three components:a) research in nanobiomaterials from natural waste, b) development of a minor course for undergraduates in MSE, and c) support the careers of young faculty members in MSE. The research projects will generate new knowledge about the use of waste materials to produce sustainable products and address the serious environmental issue of dealing with waste products by conducting the following: 1) chemical synthesis and analysis, surface studies, processing and performance evaluation of a variety of nanobiomaterials derived from natural waste; 2) development of biocompatible and biodegradable polymer scaffolds for biomedical applications and 3) development of food packaging polymer composite films with antimicrobial and pathogen resistance. The project will provide start-up funds for junior faculty members and offer a minor in Materials Science and Engineering for all STEM undergraduates at TU with the intention of increasing the pool of students entering the graduate program.

ProgramElement.Text: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-RISE: Enhancement of Research and Educational Infrastructure in Nanobiomaterials Science and Engineering at Tuskegee University

 

Vijaya K Rangari, Shaik Jeelani, Temesgen Samuel, Shaik Zainuddin and Mahesh Hosur

The National Science Foundation (NSF) has been funding the Research Infrastructure in Materials Science and Engineering (RISE) grants to Tuskegee University (TU) since 2004. The grants have allowed TU to significantly enhance its research and educational capabilities in Materials Science and Engineering and provide funds for junior faculty. Through this current grant, (TU) is elevating its Materials Science and Engineering program to a higher level so that its impact is considerably be broadened.  We are implementing the program in three following components.

 

a) to enhance research capability in extraction, synthesis and characterization of nanobiomaterials from waste materials for biomedical, food packaging and other industrial applications, b) to develop and implement an undergraduate minor in Materials Science and Engineering for all STEM undergraduates, and c) to groom young faculty members by continuing the very successful ?Start-Up Funds for Junior Faculty? program, to enable them to become productive in research and education in Materials Science and Engineering

 

We have successfully completed fifteen research projects which cover a broad area in synthesis, characterization and applications of waste materials.

1) Synthesis of bio based silica nanoparticles from waste sugar cane bagasse and rice husk,  2) Nano Silica-Carbon-Silver ternary hybrid induced antimicrobial composite films for food packaging application, 3)Synthesis, of CaSiO3 nanoparticles for biomedical and polymer filler applications, 4) Fabrication of nanoparticles/polymer nanocomposite scaffolds using electrospinning and forcespinning for  bone regeneration applications, 5) Fabrication of flexible polymer film blend of  poly (butylene-co-adipate) terephthalate (PBAT) and Poly lactic acid (PLA), 6)Tough aliphatic-aromatic copolyester and chicken egg white flexible biopolymer blend with bacteriostatic effects, 7) Halloysite Nanotube Reinforced Poly (3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate) Films, 8) Thermal, Durability and Biodegradation Properties h)Mechanical, Fire Retardant, Water Absorption and Soil Biodegradation Properties of Poly (3-hydroxy-butyrate-co-3-valerate) Nanofilms, 9) Bioactive Tissue Engineering Scaffolds Derived from Egg and Sea Shell Waste, 10) Mechanical, Microstructural and Soil Degradation Behavior of Jute/PHBV Composites, 11) The Effects of Carbon Derived from Coconut Shell Powder in PBAT/PLA Composites, 12) Development of 3D printing technique for chicken feather powder infused biodegradable polymer films, 13) Development of 3D printing of Polycarbonate/Silica Polymer Nanocomposites, 14) Development of 3D printing technique for polymer thin films incorporated carbon from coconut shell powder, 15) Reinforcement of Spent Coffee Ground Derived Biochar in Epoxy Polymer Using 3D Printing Technique

 

We have successfully developed a minor in MSE program and developed 3 new courses:  a) MSEG 0401/MSEG 0501: Materials and Society, 3 cr. b). MSEG 0402/MSEG 0502: Introduction to Biomaterials Science and Engineering, 3cr. c). MSEG 0491/MSEG 0591: Research in Materials Science and Engineering. Every semester at least two courses were offered. More than 200 students took these course for this minor degree or elective.

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2021
Modified by: Vijaya K Rangari
